markdownRemark.html:
â€A class should only have one reason to changeâ€ is a mantra that Object-Oriented advocates have chanted for years. Dubbed the â€œSingle Responsibility Principleâ€ (SRP), it remains somewhat abstract till this day âœ¨. Abstract enough that Robert Martin, who coined the term, tried to explain the SRP again in a 2014 blog post - 14 years after he first wrote about it!

That blog post begins by referencing and quoting a 1972 paper, â€On the Criteria To Be Used in Decomposing Systems into Modulesâ€ (what a mouthful) by David Parnas:

â€œWe have tried to demonstrate by these examples that it is almost always incorrect to begin the decomposition of a system into modules on the basis of a flowchart.

We propose instead that one begins with a list of difficult design decisions or design decisions which are likely to change. Each module is then designed to hide such a decision from the others.â€

The paper seemed significant, as Martin wrote that the SRP appeared â€œto align with Parnasâ€™ formulationâ€. Could it demystify the SRP? What exactly was this paper about?

The System: KWAC Index

In the paper, Parnas sets the stage - he would compare two approaches (â€œcriteriaâ€) for modularizing a system, showing that one provided superior flexibility. That system was a KWAC (KeyWord Alongside Context) index.

KWAC was one of many indexing systems used for technical manuals. Important words in sentences were emphasised by â€œrotatingâ€ or â€œcircularly shiftingâ€ the word such that it was the first. For example, Office 2003 Timesaving Techniques for Dummies. would become Dummies. Office 2003 Timesaving Techniques for, as below:

The next sections explain Parnasâ€™ modularizations. This video explanation (starting from 17:16) helped me visualise and understand them, and Iâ€™ll borrow liberally from it ğŸ™‡â€â™‚ï¸.

Modularization 1: â€œFlowchartâ€

In the first modularization, Parnas modelled the problem as a flowchart, using the individual steps to break apart the modules (an approach which Iâ€™m guilty of taking!): Itâ€™s worth highlighting a significant design decision not obvious above, which was to have all modules share a common data structure to store the input. All modules would use this structure, which has implications that become clearer later.

Hereâ€™s what each module did:

  • Input

    • Parses the input text file and stores in memory with an array-like structure weâ€™ll call â€œCharactersâ€, with 4 characters per element (explained around 23:36 in the video).

    • For example, given the file:

      # cat input.txt
Program Development
On The Criteria
    • This would be parsed and stored as:
    • The module also outputs â€œLinesâ€, which is an array stating the start of each line (e.g. 1, 21 above)

  • Circular Shifter

    • Given â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œLinesâ€, it outputs an array of â€œShiftsâ€.
    • Each â€œShiftâ€ stored the line number, as well as the starting index of each word.

  • Alphabetizer

    • Given â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œShiftsâ€, it sorts the â€œShiftsâ€ alphabetically and outputs them as â€œAlphabetizedâ€.

  • Output

    • Given the â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œAlphabetizedâ€ shifts, outputs the KWAC index, something like:

      # Using the golang example from the video
# go run m1/main.go input.txt
Criteria | On The [2]
Development | Program [1]
On The Criteria [2]
Program Development [1]
The Criteria | On [2]

A helpful visual summary of all the different data structures:

Modularization 2: â€œInformation Hidingâ€

In this modularization, Parnas uses the criteria of â€œInformation Hidingâ€. The definition is worth mentioning for itâ€™s relevance to the SRP:

Every module in the second decomposition is characterized by its knowledge of a design decision which it hides from all others. Its interface or definition was chosen to reveal as little as possible about its inner workings.

Practically speaking, he encapsulates (hides) how the input is stored via â€œLine Storageâ€, and changes the dependency of subsequent modules. Of note, these changes remove global reliance on the stored input: What each module does:

  • Input

    • Like Modularization 1, also parses the input, but this time inserts it into a Line Storage.

  • Line Storage

    • Think of it like an Object that has methods for inserting and retrieving characters by line (e.g. get Character 5 of Line 1, Word 2)
    • Other convenience methods are also provided (e.g. counting words).

  • Circular Shifter

    • Generates the circular shifts from Line Storage.
    • Instead of outputting â€œShiftsâ€, the module itself provides an interface (like an Object) similar to Line Storage, but allows retrieval of characters by their shifts instead of lines (e.g. get Character 5 of Shift 1, Word 2).

  • Alphabetizer

    • Retrieving the characters from Circular Shifter, this modules sorts by alphabet and remembers the shifts.
    • Instead of outputting the â€œAlphabetizedâ€ shifts, the module provides a method to get Circular Shifts in order (e.g. tell me the shift thatâ€™s in the 2nd sorted position).

  • Output

    • Uses Alphabetizer and Circular Shifter to generate the KWAC Index.

Comparison: Changeability

While other comparisons were made (see the Afterword section), the section on changeability speaks most to the SRP. Parnas begins by suggesting some â€œlikelyâ€ change scenarios. Most require many modules to be updated in Modularization 1, but have a much smaller blast radius in Modularization 2:

Scenario Modularization 1 Modularization 2
Deciding to store â€œCharactersâ€ in a different medium (e.g. filesystem) instead of memory All modules Line Storage
Deciding on a different way to store the â€œCharactersâ€ (e.g. group by words instead of every 4 characters) All Modules Line Storage
Deciding to store the full sentences of each circular shift instead of their indexes Circular Shifter, Alphabetizer, Output Circular Shifter
Deciding to change â€œAlphabetizedâ€ generation to be lazy or distributed (possibly due to a large dataset?) Difficult to achieve as computation must be completed before output Achievable as Output doesnâ€™t need all the shifts to be â€œalphabetizedâ€

The conclusion is that choosing to split by â€œinformation hidingâ€ results in code that is easier to change!

Conclusion

So where does the paper leave us in relation to the SRP? Personally, I left with a better understanding of why it was important - it should result in code that is easier to change. However, even with the (helpful) example, it seems applying the SRP remains hyper-contextual, and more an art than science.

Whatâ€™s your framework for beginning â€œwith a list of difficult design decisions or design decisions which are likely to changeâ€?

Further Reading:

  • Diego Ontaroâ€™s talk and his example code in Go.
  • KWIC Indexes in Wikipedia - note that the original paper calls it a KWIC index, but as Diego Ontaro explains, itâ€™s actually a KWAC index.
  • Parnasâ€™ Original Papers: 1972 (which references an earlier paper written in 1971 with more implementation details).
  • Adrian Colyerâ€™s elegant and higher-level summary of the same paper.

Afterword

I apologise for the mix of American and British english ğŸ˜†.

The bits of the paper I deliberately left out:

  • Comparisons:

    • correctness and comprehensibility were deemed similar for both Modularizations, so I left it out.
    • independent development: Modularization 2 was deemed better, as in Modularization 1 the devs building each module would have to agree upon and develop the shared input storage.

  • Efficiency:

    • I had trouble understanding this bit, think it had more relevance to the programming systems of the time: â€œ(Modularization 2), if implemented with the conventional assumption that a module consists of one or more subroutines, will be less efficient in most cases.â€
  • An anecdotal example of building a translator was given in further support of â€œInformation Hidingâ€.
  • Thereâ€™s a critique of the Modularization 2â€™s Circular Shifter based on a somewhat arbitrary definition - the shifts were ordered corresponding to their line numbers in the original input, which encoded that assumption into other modules that interacted with it. It felt like an arbitrarily bad decision made to illustrate a point, and felt hard to fit in the flow of this post.
  • The critique also included some â€œgeneralisableâ€ decomposition criteria, but they seemed somewhat low level (thereâ€™s mention of assembly) and I found it difficult to draw parallels in todayâ€™s higher-level programming languages.
  • Thereâ€™s a distinction made between a â€œhierarchical structureâ€ (a separate paper which I havenâ€™t read) and â€œinformation hidingâ€.

frontmatter.title: What does a 1972 paper have to do with the Single Responsibility Principle?
frontmatter.description: While trying to explain the Single Responsibility Principle, it's originator calls attention to a paper written in the last decade. Why was this paper so significant? Let's find out!
